This report shows that complete control of the degree of alkali exchange is possible by controlling the pH strength, and that is possible to distinguish the selectivity of the cations themselves in the lactic acid (LA) dehydration reaction by excluding undesired active sites arising from excess salts. We discovered that strong base conditions induced by alkali hydroxides (e.g., KOH) increase the degree of alkali ion exchange, and that in the absence of additional salts−such as halogen anions, oxides−the KOH-ZSM-5 catalyst exhibited high acrylic acid (AA) selectivity (∼70%) and durability (100 h). Characterization via temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) and pyridine-infrared (Py-IR) analysis revealed a full exchange of the protons bound to the Si–O–Al sites with potassium in commercial ZSM-5. In addition, structural pore expansion due to the desilication by KOH leads to significant enhancement in the selectivity for AA. The mechanistic impact of KOH treatment on lactic acid dehydration is also systematically verified by in situ IR spectroscopy. Graphical Abstract Keywords Biochemicals Lactic acid Acrylic acid Zeolites pH strength Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Growth of the petrochemical field has led to the increasing emission of greenhouse gases from hydrocarbon-based products, which has become a major problem worldwide [1]. Eco-friendly alternatives to manufacturing of products avoiding petrochemical processes have been discussed, and among numerous alternatives, research on the utilization of biomass resources that can be produced in a carbon-neutral manner is emerging as a key technology [2,3]. Recently, owing to the development of the bioindustry, a stable supply of biomass-based platform chemicals is now available, and high-value-added materials from mass-produced biomass-derived materials are in demand for replacing petrochemicals [4–7]. Among the numerous biomass-derived monomers, lactic acid (LA) produced through sugar fermentation is attracting interest as an excellent raw material because it can be converted into high-value-added acrylic acid (AA) via simple dehydration [7,8]. However, in the dehydration of lactic acid, side products are preferentially generated because of the high reactivity due to the proximity of the carboxyl and hydroxyl groups in lactic acid, which increases the overall process cost owing to the additional exhaustive separation and purification units [9–11] ( Fig. 1). Therefore, the design of active, selective, and highly durable catalysts for the effective dehydration of lactic acid molecules has received increasing attention. Various heterogeneous solid-acid catalysts (WxOy, TiO2, MoOx, phosphoric, and silicophosphoric acids) are known to be active in the traditional dehydration of petroleum-derived species. However, these traditional dehydration reactions do not exhibit the expected high selectivity for LA dehydration [8]. Alkali-modified zeolites recently achieved appreciable selectivity for AA production, suggesting a potential direction for future catalyst development using zeolites [12]. The well-ordered microporous structure and the acid-base properties, which can be tuned through ion exchange, make zeolites ideal base materials for improved catalyst design [13]. Specifically, alkali-ion-exchanged zeolites such as K-ZSM-5 and Na-Y have shown high selectivity (50−75 %) in the dehydration of lactic acid [14]. To date, various alkali and alkaline-earth metal salts have been employed to further improve the catalyst selectivity; in general, these metal salts effectively weaken the strong-acid sites in the catalyst, thereby suppressing unwanted side reactions such as acetaldehyde (AD) generation through decarboxylation [15–17]. Many previous studies have shown that regardless of the zeolite form, zeolites impregnated with potassium salts are among the best catalysts for lactic acid dehydration [10,15]. By ion exchange of NaY zeolite with potassium nitrates, Sun et al. increased the AA yield from 14% to ∼50%, demonstrating the superiority of potassium cations over sodium [15]. In addition, by directly impregnating NaY zeolite with potassium halides, an increased AA yield of ∼66% was obtained, attributed to the role of halogen residues in enhancing the basicity of the catalyst [18]. More recently, Yan et al. achieved the highest AA yield of ∼80% to date by treating the Na-ZSM-5 structure with KBr solutions, attributed to the weakening of the strong acid/base sites; they postulated that the deposited excess KBr or K2O, in conjunction with the charge-balance K cation, may play a role in the reduced acidity [10]. It was recently found that catalysts modified with sodium phosphate salts exhibit considerably enhanced AA selectivity [19,20]. For example, Zhang et al. obtained an AA yield of ∼58.4% by effectively weakening the acidity of NaY zeolites through sodium phosphate modification [19]. In line with the results achieved with potassium halides, the enhanced selectivity of zeolites impregnated with sodium phosphate salts is likely due to the effective removal of even a small amount of Brønsted acid sites from the surface of the NaY catalyst due to the deposition of sodium phosphate particles. Furthermore, the same authors further improved the surface properties of NaY by forming nanocrystals and reported a high AA yield of ∼74% owing to the enhanced distribution of existing sodium phosphate on the zeolite [20]. Other researchers added sodium phosphate to ZSM-5 through desilication-induced pore enlargement and reported a high AA yield of ∼75% [14]. Considering the earlier studies, it seems that various salts or oxides remained on the zeolite surface after ion exchange or impregnation, and acted as secondary active sites or quenchers of the strong-acid sites, leading to high-activity zeolite catalysts for AA production [10,21]. Similarly, our research group recently found that the ion exchange method inevitably leaves excess salt on the surface beyond that required for charge-balance with Al unless the catalyst is repeatedly washed with copious amounts of water. For example, an unintentionally small amount of sodium residue in Na-ZSM-5 (Na/Al ∼ 1.2) increased the LA dehydration selectivity to ∼80 %, compared to ∼30 % AA selectivity with Na-ZSM-5 with a Na/Al ratio of 1.0 [22]. We noted that numerous research groups have not considered the promotional role of residual alkali salts on the catalyst surface and simply focused on the relationship between the acidity/basicity determined by temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) analysis and the activity. Therefore, in this study, for the first time, we reveal the intrinsic activity of pure cations in LA dehydration by excluding excess cations through a thorough washing process. Moreover, we address the impact of the type of anion in the alkali salts on the degree of ion exchange and the corresponding activity change in relation to the pH. It has been shown that alkali cations interact with zeolites via two mechanisms depending on the pH of the solution: (1) conventional ion exchange at the Al sites in the framework and (2) strong electrostatic adsorption (SEA) [23]. The former is dominant at low and neutral pH, whereas the latter is dominant under highly basic conditions (pH > 8). Thus, high pH can result in more effective cation transfer by SEA and even “overexchange” of cations at the silanol groups beyond the nominal ion exchange capacity of the zeolites. Herein, for the first time, we investigate the effect of anions from various salts on the catalyst activity at different pH, track the correlation between the degree of exchange and activity by SEA, and ultimately overcome the cation exchange limitations of typical H-form ZSM-5 catalysts to achieve selective dehydration of LA to AA. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A commercial NH4-ZSM-5 (SiAl = 15) zeolite purchased from Zeolyst was calcined at 550 °C for 9 h at a rate of 3 °C/min under air atmosphere to remove surface adsorbates. Through calcination, NH4 + was converted to H+ in the ZSM-5 zeolite. For alkali treatment, 5 g of H-ZSM-5 and 50 mL of alkali metal aqueous solution (0.5 M) were stirred in an oil-bath at 80 °C for 12 h. The resulting precipitate was washed with distilled water several times using a centrifuge until neutral pH was achieved and then dried in an oven at 90° C for 12 h. Finally, the product was calcined at 550 °C under air atmosphere for 7 h at a rate of 3° C/min. All of the catalysts were prepared under identical conditions, and the respective samples are denoted as M-ZSM-5 (M = NaNO3, NaHCO3, Na2HPO4, NaOH, KOH, RbOH, and CsOH) according to the names of the samples used. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The cation content and trace element compositions of the catalyst samples were determined using an inductively-coupled plasma (ICP) analyzer (Perkin Elmer Optima 4300DU ICP-AES and Thermo Elemental X-7 ICP-MS) with high-temperature argon plasma as the ion source. The specific surface areas, pore size distributions, and pore volumes of the catalysts were analyzed by N2 adsorption using a specific surface area analyzer (nitrogen adsorption/desorption, BELSORP-mini II). The specific surface area and pore properties were calculated by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and t-plot methods. The crystal structure of the catalyst was analyzed using a powder X-ray diffraction spectrometer (P-XRD, Shimadzu) at room temperature. Cu-Kα X-rays (λ = 0.15406 nm) were generated at 40 kV and 30 mA, and data were collected in the 2θ range of 5–60° with a step size of 0.02° and a time per step of 30. A pH meter (CAS pH meter) was used to measure the pH of the aqueous solution used for ion exchange during synthesis of the catalyst. Temperature-programmed desorption (NH3 and CO2-TPD, BELCAT-M) was used to confirm the acid–base properties of the catalyst sites. The catalyst was pre-treated under He flow at 500 °C for 2 h, after which 5% NH3 or CO2/He gas was adsorbed on the catalyst over the course of 30 min. Thereafter, the gas was desorbed by heating from 50 °C to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min and quantified. 29Si and 27Al solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (SS NMR) spectra were obtained using 4 mm CPMAS probes and a 500 MHz Bruker ADVANCE III HD NMR spectrometer at the National Center for Inter-University Research Facilities (Seoul National University, Republic of Korea). Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform (DRIFT) spectra were obtained using a Nicolet™ IS50 FT-IR instrument (Thermo Fisher Scientific®). Additionally, a Praying Mantis™ high-temperature reaction chamber (HARRICK®) was used to acquire in situ IR spectra. These experiments were performed under N2 purging. To completely remove moisture from the catalyst for the experiments, all catalysts were heated to 400 °C. After the adsorption of vaporized LA on the catalyst surface by exposure for 15 min, the IR spectra were collected after a stabilization period of 10 min in each temperature range. 2.3 Analysis of dehydration reaction The top-down fixed-bed reactor used for LA dehydration was equipped with a quartz tube (inner diameter: 10 mm; length: 300 mm) and was operated at atmospheric pressure. The quartz tube was filled with a catalyst layer (particle size: 200–400 μm, weight: 0.7–0.8 g) between quartz wool, and quartz beads were placed on top. As a pre-treatment process, moisture was removed using high-purity N2 gas at 325 °C. The reaction was performed at 325 °C for 16 h, and the reactant (10 wt% LA aqueous solution) was pumped into a quartz tube at 3 mL/h using an injection syringe and conveyed through the catalyst bed by N2 gas at a rate of 25 mL/min. The resulting liquid reactant cooled through a condenser was collected and analyzed using gas chromatography (GC, Agilent 8890) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and HP-FFAP capillary column (0.32 mm × 25 m). All parameters associated with the quantitative analysis were calculated based on the total carbon balance. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 Composition and structural properties Table 1 shows the elemental compositions of the Na-modified ZSM-5 and MOH-modified ZSM-5 catalysts, as determined by ICP analysis. First, the Na/Al ratio of Na-ZSM-5 decreased in the following order: NaOH-ZSM-5 (1.18) > Na2HPO4-ZSM-5 (0.90) > NaHCO3-ZSM-5 (0.86) > NaNO3-ZSM-5 (0.83), which corresponds to the decreasing solution pH. The increased solution pH induced deprotonation of the ZSM-5 surface, thereby resulting in more effective cation exchange through the SEA. In particular, in the case of NaOH-ZSM-5, a relatively high Na/Al ratio (1.18) was achieved, indicating the likely overexchange of sodium at the silanol sites of ZSM-5, in addition to the framework Al sites. On the contrary, the Na/Al ratios lower than 1.0 for the other catalysts suggest that cation exchange was incomplete, leaving some unexchanged proton sites in the zeolite pore. At the same time, the Si/Al ratio of the Na-modified ZSM-5 catalysts, except NaOH-ZSM-5, did not change compared to that of the parent H-ZSM-5 [24,25]. However, the Si/Al ratio of the NaOH-modified ZSM-5 catalyst decreased considerably from 16.9 to 14.3, suggesting that high solution basicity (pH ∼ 14) leads to some desilication of the ZSM-5 structure, as expected. Because hydroxides exhibited the greatest degree of ion exchange, alkali hydroxides were employed for cation exchange in the subsequent experiments. For different alkali metals (M+) MOH-ZSM-5 catalysts, the M/Al ratio gradually decreased in the following order: NaOH-ZSM-5 (1.18) > KOH-ZSM-5 (1.01) > RbOH-ZSM-5 (0.98) > CsOH-ZSM-5 (0.89). This corresponds to the increasing order of the cation size (Na < K < Rb < Cs), suggesting that the smaller the cation size, the higher the cation exchange rate. The relatively low M/Al value for Cs (∼0.89), even with the use of hydroxide, is an steric effect because Cs is too large to fit into the small pores of ZSM-5 [13]. In addition, for all of the MOH-modified ZSM-5 catalysts, the Si/Al ratio decreased significantly from 16.9 to 12.9−14.3, suggesting obvious desilication attributed to the strong hydroxide (-OH) contained in the alkaline aqueous solutions (MOH). Notably, the degree of the desilication was dependent on the type of cation, showing the larger cation leads to the greater extent of desilication except KOH. This can be due to the faster dissociation of MOH with the larger cation size [26]. However, the in-situ release of the acidic protons during the cation exchange can also affect this dissociation kinetics. This is the reason why KOH had the greatest degree of the desilication. The specific surface areas and porosities of Na- and MOH-modified ZSM-5 were investigated through N2 adsorption–desorption measurements (Table 1). The specific surface area and pore characteristics of ZSM-5 modified with NaNO3, NaHCO3, and Na2HPO4 did not change significantly compared to those of the parent H-ZSM-5, and these catalysts were mainly microporous. By contrast, for NaOH-ZSM-5, the micropore volume decreased substantially from 0.15 cm3/g to 0.05 cm3/g. It appears that the strong alkali treatment leads to a decrease in the microporosity through desilication. However, the total pore volume increased from 0.26 cm3/g to 0.41 cm3/g owing to the formation of new mesopores. Although the presence of micropores in zeolites is advantageous for conformationally selective reactions, the micropores can limit the diffusion of LA molecules; thus, pore expansion by desilication may improve the LA reactivity through enhanced mass transfer [27,28]. For the other MOH-modified ZSM-5 catalysts, the trends were similar to those observed for NaOH-ZSM-5; the micropore volume decreased rapidly from 0.15 cm3/g to 0.07−0.06 cm3/g and the mesopore volume increased from 0.11 cm3/g to 0.20−0.31 at the expense of the micropores. Pore enlargement may also enable the large cations to access the Al sites inside the pore, increasing the degree of cation exchange. The XRD patterns of the parent H-ZSM-5 zeolite and alkali-metal-modified catalysts are shown in Fig. 2. The characteristic peaks (2θ = 7.8°, 8.7°, 22.94°, 23.6°, and 24.26°) of the MFI structure were observed for all catalysts, verifying that the crystallinity of all catalysts was maintained [14]. However, for NaOH-ZSM-5, the intensity of the peaks decreased slightly compared to that of the parent H-ZSM-5, suggesting somewhat lower crystallinity of the former likely through desilication. By contrast, the intensity of the peaks of ZSM-5 modified with NaNO3, NaHCO3, and Na2HPO4 were similar to those of the parent catalyst, indicating that the crystal structure of H-ZSM-5 was intact at pH < ∼9.3. Similar to NaOH-ZSM-5, the XRD peaks of all MOH-modified ZSM-5 samples (i.e., KOH, RbOH, and CsOH) exhibited a significant decrease in intensity, and the extent of the reduction was more severe than that of NaOH-ZSM-5. In particular, the largest reduction in the peak intensity was observed for CsOH-ZSM-5, resulting in the disappearance of the peaks at 7.8° and 8.7°. This may be due to the reduced contrast between the pore and the zeolite framework. Because the peak intensity at low angels is related to the contrast in electron density of the pore, as the pore is filled with larger cations (i.e., high electron density cations), the difference in electron density decreases to a greater extent, resulting in lower peak intensities [13,29]. Importantly, the crystallinity decrease observed for MOH-ZSM-5 agrees well with the reduction in the micropore volumes measured by N2 physisorption, as shown in Table 1. Overall, no new peaks other than those of ZSM-5 were observed in the XRD patterns of any of the samples. 3.1.2 Acid and base properties NH3- and CO2-TPD were used to investigate the amount and strength of the acid/base sites in the parent H-ZSM-5 and alkali-metal-modified ZSM-5; the results are shown in Fig. 3 and Table 2, respectively. First, as shown in Fig. 3(a), ammonia was desorbed from H-ZSM-5 at three distinct temperatures: 150, 200, and 410 °C. The peak observed at the high temperature of 410 °C can be assigned to the strong-acid sites of H-ZSM-5, and the two peaks observed below 200 °C indicate relatively weak/medium acid sites. The strong-acid sites of H-ZSM-5 are likely to be Brønsted acid sites that donate protons, and the relatively weak/medium acid sites may be Lewis acid sites arising from Al3+ [5]. For all of the Na-modified ZSM-5 catalysts, the peak at ∼410 °C, corresponding to the strong-acid sites, almost disappeared owing to ion exchange of the protons of H-ZSM-5 with Na cations, as expected. Instead, a new peak emerged at ∼300 °C for all Na-modified ZSM-5, which can be assigned to the charge-balance Na cations, acting as Lewis acid sites [10,14]. Furthermore, the total number of acid sites increased in the order: NaNO3-ZSM-5< NaHCO3-ZSM-5 < Na2HPO4-ZSM-5 < NaOH-ZSM-5, which corresponds to the increasing order of the Na/Al ratio (Table 2). Overall, this suggests that the TPD peaks below 400 °C is related to the Na cations coordinated to framework Al sites. Furthermore, the Py-IR analysis confirmed that Lewis acid sites were more dominant than Brønsted acid sites in all Na-ZSM-5 samples, which is in line with the TPD results (Table S1). As the pH of the aqueous solution increases (i.e., more basic), the “over-exchange” of sodium at the silanol groups through SEA or the physical deposition onto zeolite framework as sodium oxide can happen, affecting the catalyst basicity. As shown in Fig. 3(b), for parent H-ZSM-5, only a single broad desorption peak for CO2 centered at 200 °C was observed, ascribed to medium-base sites. On the contrary, two new, distinct peaks appeared at 100 and 300 °C in the desorption profiles of all Na-modified ZSM-5 samples, related to weak- and strong-base sites, respectively, suggesting the possible existence of two different type of base sites. Interestingly, the peak of the strong-base sites (300 °C) became progressively weaker with increasing pH of the aqueous solution (i.e., NaNO3 < Na2HPO4 < NaOH), whereas the intensity of the peak corresponding to the weak-base sites (100 °C) increased at the expense of the peak of the strong-base site. Specifically, the number of weakly and strongly basic sites for NaNO3-ZSM-5 were 0.010 and 0.172 mmol/g, respectively, compared with 0.069 and 0.062 mmol/g for NaOH-ZSM-5. Although the nature of these two peaks is unclear, the overall basicity appeared to weaken with increasing solution pH. The acidity–basicity characterization of the MOH-modified ZSM-5 is summarized in Fig. 3(c), (d). First, in the analysis of the acidity, the peak at 410 °C, related to strong-acid sites of the parent H-ZSM-5, i.e., the Brønsted acid sites, was not observed for any of the MOH-modified ZSM-5 catalysts. Notably, compared to NaOH-ZSM-5, for which two broad peaks were observed at 190 and 400 °C, the desorption profiles of KOH-, RbOH-, and CsOH-modified ZSM-5 showed only a single narrow peak at ca. 150 °C, which corresponds to weak-acid sites. This is because the Lewis acid strength of alkali zeolites decreases as the size of the alkali cations increases; thus, Na cations exhibit the highest affinity for NH3 [5]. In addition to the acid strength, the size of the cations affects the number of acidic sites. The number of weakly acidic sites decreased in the following order: NaOH-ZSM-5 (1.854 mmol/g) > KOH-ZSM-5 (1.313 mmol/g) > RbOH-ZSM-5 (1.031 mmol/g) > CsOH-ZSM-5 (0.410 mmol/g), indicating that the larger the cation size, the smaller the number of acidic sites. Considering the progressive decrease in the surface area of ZSM-5 with increasing cation size, the larger cations may block the pore entrances more significantly, thereby making the other acid sites inaccessible and decreasing the overall acidity. MOH-ZSM-5 showed diverse base properties depending on the cation type. Compared to NaOH-ZSM-5 with distinct weak- (100 °C) and strong-base sites (300 °C), the desorption profile of KOH-ZSM-5 exhibited a large peak centered at 200 °C, with a small shoulder peak at 100 °C, indicating that the strong-base sites are converted into weak/medium-base sites by potassium. Notably, the desorption curves of RbOH- and CsOH-ZSM-5 showed a single peak at 170 and 150 °C, respectively, corresponding to the medium-base sites; these catalysts have weaker base strength than KOH-ZSM-5. The results suggest that the CO2-adsorption strength increases as the size of the alkali cation decreases because of increased basicity, as previously reported [15,30]. Moreover, the number of base sites decreased in the following order: KOH-ZSM-5 (0.195 mmol/g)> RbOH-ZSM-5 (0.156 mmol/g)> CsOH-ZMS-5 (0.116 mmol/g), which is the inverse order of the cation size, as is the case for the number of acid sites. Numerous works have demonstrated that weak and medium base sites are effective for LA dehydration [5,15,31]. KOH-, RbOH-, and CsOH-modified ZSM-5 do not have strongly basic sites, suggesting that these catalysts may be selective for LA dehydration. Among the catalysts, KOH-ZSM-5 had the highest number of base sites. To determine the types of acidic sites, the NaNO3-ZSM-5 and KOH-ZSM-5 catalysts were subjected to pyridine-IR spectroscopy (Table S1). KOH-ZSM-5 has a nearly insignificant amount (0.004 mmol/g) of Brønsted acid (BA) sites and mainly comprises of Lewis acid (LA) sites (0.572 mmol/g). By contrast, NaNO3-ZSM-5 clearly has a distinct amount (0.148 mmol/g) of BA sites, and a large amount of LA sites (0.654 mmol/g), suggesting that unexchanged proton sites remained in the catalyst, which is consistent with the ICP-measured Na/Al ratio of NaNO3-ZSM-5 (∼0.83). Overall, this IR analysis confirmed that hydroxide treatment resulted in extremely effective cation exchange, efficiently removing the strong BA sites. 3.1.3 27Al and 29Si solid-state NMR 27Al and 29Si SS NMR analysis were performed to see the presence of extra-framework Al sites and the change in the local coordination environment of silicon after the KOH treatment ( Fig. 4). In the case of H-ZSM-5, the two peaks are observed at around 55 ppm and 0 ppm on Al-NMR, which correspond to tetrahedral Al in zeolite framework and octahedral Al species in extra-framework, respectively. This indicates that some extra-framework Al species existed in the commercial catalyst, possibly acting as additional active sites. However, after KOH treatment (i.e., KOH-ZSM-5), the peak related to the extra-framework Al species at 0 ppm was not observed, and only that of tetrahedral Al was observed at 55 ppm. This suggests that KOH treatment removed the extra-framework Al debris. Moreover, the peak at 55 ppm became more intense after KOH treatment, possibly because of the desilication effect. Fig. 4 (b) shows the 29Si-NMR profiles of H-ZSM-5 and KOH-ZSM-5. The peaks of Si species in a typical zeolite framework appear in the region of −100 to −115 ppm. Specifically, the peaks at −113 and −107 ppm are related to the 4Si(0Al) and 3Si(1Al) species of ZSM-5, respectively [26]. Two peaks were clearly observed in this range for both H-ZSM-5 and KOH-ZSM-5, suggesting that the ZSM-5 framework remained largely intact even after 12 h of treatment with strong KOH. This result is in good agreement with the N2 physisorption and XRD data, indicating the intact microporous and crystalline properties of KOH-ZSM-5. However, the peak at −113 ppm became somewhat less intense after KOH treatment, suggesting the removal of silicon in the 4Si(0Al) sites. This is consistent with the results of previous studies in which the intensity of the peak around −113 ppm was reduced through concentrated base treatment [27]. On the contrary, new peaks were observed at −93 and −100 ppm for KOH-ZSM-5. These peaks are attributed to silanol groups exposed on the zeolite surface via desilication [26]. Therefore, it is possible that the strong base treatment results in ion exchange between the silanol groups and potassium, thereby forming new active sites for Si–O–K [32]. Although the exact catalytic role of these sites in the LA dehydration has not been verified, multiple studies have shown that the formation of additional base sites such as halide salts or alkali oxides deposited on the zeolite surface can help improve AA selectivity [18,22]. Similarly, the Si–O–K may act as the base site for promoting the AA selectivity. However, future experiments need to be undertaken to elucidate the role of this type of active sites. 3.2 Catalytic activity 3.2.1 Effect of anions of sodium salts The LA dehydration activity of Na-exchanged ZSM-5 with sodium salts of various anions (NO3 -, HCO3 -, HPO4 -2, OH-) was investigated. Fig. 5 shows the conversion and selectivity of H-ZSM-5 and the Na-modified ZSM-5 catalysts. Although LA conversion was almost complete for all catalysts, the Na-modified catalysts showed much higher AA selectivity than H-ZSM-5. In the case of H-ZSM-5, the AA selectivity was only ∼0.2%, and the majority of the product was AD, with 95% selectivity. The strong-acid sites of H-ZSM-5 (Brønsted acid sites) mainly induce decarboxylation to AD rather than dehydration, as reported previously [14]. By contrast, for the Na-modified catalyst, the product selectivity clearly shifted toward AA production (between 7% and 30%), and the AA selectivity was dependent on type of anion in the sodium salts used for the ion exchange process. Importantly, the AA selectivity was correlated with the pH of the exchange solution, dictated by the anion type; the higher the solution pH, the higher the AA selectivity, as shown in Fig. 6. The correlation between the solution pH and AA selectivity can be explained by the change in the degree of Na exchange and its corresponding impact on the surface acidity/basicity. The Na/Al ratio increased progressively from 0.83 to 1.18 with increasing solution pH because of more effective sodium adsorption through the SEA. In addition, an increase in the Na loading led to an increase in the total acidity from 1.305 to 1.854 mmol/g. In the case of the basicity, the solution pH affected the nature of the basic sites qualitatively, converting the strongly basic sites to weakly basic sites with increasing pH (see Fig. 3). Overall, the greater the degree of Na exchange, the higher the total acidity, and the lower the base strength (with increasing solution pH), the higher the AA selectivity. In contrast to NaNO3-, NaHCO3-, and Na2HPO4-modified ZSM-5, which showed only incremental changes in the AA selectivity, NaOH-ZSM-5 showed a remarkable increase in the AA selectivity of more than 15%. This dramatic increase in the AA selectivity can be explained by the “over-exchange” of sodium (i.e., Na/Al ∼1.18), possibly at the silanol defect sites, as evidenced by 29Si NMR. The excess sodium can ultimately act as additional active sites, modifying the product selectivity [25]. Alternatively, the aqueous solution of NaOH (pH 14.0) significantly affected the pore characteristics of Na-ZSM-5 through desilication. The strong-alkali treatment, such as with NaOH, induces desilication to form the hierarchical structure of ZSM-5 [33], thereby affecting the catalyst activity by enhancing the diffusion of molecules. In conclusion, the combined effects of the additional active sites generated from excess Na and the increased surface area plausibly played a role in the increased AA selectivity after NaOH treatment. 3.2.2 Effect of cations of alkali hydroxides Fig. 7 shows the conversion and selectivity of the various alkali-modified ZSM-5 catalysts, as well as images of the spent catalysts, which provide qualitative insight into the degree of coke formation. Overall, MOH-modified ZSM-5 (M = K, Rb, Cs) showed much higher AA selectivity than NaOH-ZSM-5, and the AA selectivity decreased in the order: KOH-ZSM-5 (65%) > RbOH-ZSM-5 (64%) > CsOH-ZSM-5 (50%) > NaOH-ZSM-5 (30%). In general, the observed AA selectivity trend correlated well with the acidic and basic surface properties of the catalysts, as shown in Fig. 3(c) and (d). The low-selectivity NaOH-ZSM-5 has mainly acid sites of medium strength and strong-base sites. Previous studies have shown that relatively weak acid/base sites promote high AA selectivity in the dehydration of LA [8,15]. Therefore, these strong acidic/basic sites catalyze the formation of by-products such as AD, and carbon deposition. Compared to NaOH-ZSM-5, KOH-, RbOH-, and CsOH-modified ZSM-5 clearly had only weak acid sites and base sites of weak-to-medium strength, explaining their high AA selectivity. Moreover, the M/Al ratios of the catalysts, except for NaOH-ZSM-5, were in the range of 0.9–1.0, suggesting that the effect of the excess cations, which are not charge-balance cations, on the catalytic activity of these catalysts is relatively small, and the enhanced AA selectivity plausibly arises from the weakened acidic character of the larger cations. Compared to KOH- and RbOH-ZSM-5 (∼65% AA selectivity), CsOH-ZSM-5 exhibited a relatively low AA selectivity of ∼50%. This is because the Cs+ cation is the largest, hindering access to the Al sites inside the small pores of ZSM-5, thereby resulting in a low degree of cation exchange. In contrast, the AA selectivity of RbOH-ZSM-5 (∼65%) was similar to that KOH-ZSM-5, where the latter has been previously reported to be the best-performing catalyst for AA production [34,35]. The high activity of Rb cations observed in this study is attributed to the enhanced cation exchange rate induced by the SEA effect of the RbOH solution. However, in terms of the catalyst lifetime, KOH-ZSM-5 appears to be superior to RbOH-ZSM-5. As shown in Fig. 7, the color of the spent RbOH-ZSM-5 catalyst after the 16-hour reaction was dark grey, whereas the spent KOH-ZSM-5 was white, suggesting that coke deposition on the surface of RbOH-ZSM-5 was significant. TGA analysis also confirmed that the amount of coke deposition on RbOH-ZSM-5 is larger than that on KOH-ZSM-5 (2.8 wt% vs. 0.3 wt%). Overall, these results suggest that the use of K cation and hydroxide leads to suitable acid–base properties and mesopores in KOH-ZSM-5, resulting in the highest AA selectivity and lowest coke formation simultaneously. 3.3 Mechanism of LA dehydration over KOH-treated ZSM-5 In situ IR analysis was performed to confirm the mechanism of LA dehydration over the high-selectivity KOH-treated catalyst. NaNO3-ZSM-5 was also analyzed as a control sample. According to previous studies, the first reaction step is the simultaneous formation of surface lactate and BA sites via the deprotonation of lactic acid molecules on potassium. The BA formed in situ is reportedly the active site for lactate dehydration [21]. Paradoxically, these BA sites can also induce side reactions, such as decarboxylation, by competitive adsorption of new LA molecules, promoting the production of excess AD. If the adsorbed surface lactate is properly oriented toward the BA sites (i.e., the hydroxyl group interacts with the surface BA), the formation of acrylate proceeds through the E1 mechanism. The catalytic cycle ends with reverse ion exchange between the acrylate and the surface proton site, followed by the desorption of AA. In Na-Y zeolites, the formation of absorbed LA species was evidenced by peaks at 1720, 1650, and 1550 cm-1, which correspond to the CO stretching vibration of the adsorbed LA, O-C-O stretching of sodium lactate, and O-C-O stretching of sodium acrylate, respectively [21]. The in-situ formation of BA and water is evidenced by peaks in the wavenumber range of 3600−3700 cm-1. Fig. 8(a) shows the in-situ IR profiles of the NaNO3-ZSM-5 catalyst as a function of temperature. The carbonyl and hydroxyl stretching modes at 1720 cm-1 and 3650 cm-1 for LA appeared immediately after treatment at 100 °C, indicating the molecular adsorption of LA on Na-ZSM-5. However, no change in the two peaks was observed when the temperature was increased to 350 °C. The bands related to in-situ BA (3650 cm-1) and water (3600 cm-1) did not appear throughout the temperature change, suggesting that the Na-ZSM-5 catalyst cannot form surface lactate and proton sites, and thus cannot undergo the sequential dehydration reaction because of the relatively low degree of Na ion exchange. The relatively low AA selectivity of NaNO3-ZSM-5 (∼5%) also agreed well with the IR results. The IR spectrum of the KOH-treated catalyst treated at 100 °C showed a relatively intense peak at 1720 cm-1, indicating that a large amount of lactic acid is adsorbed for the same adsorption time as for NaNO3-ZSM-5. This enhanced adsorption is attributed to the combined effect of the stronger basicity of the K cations and the higher degree of K cation exchange. At the same temperature, a small lactate peak and the -OH peak of the BA sites were also observed at 1650 cm-1 at 3600 cm-1, respectively, suggesting that the first ion-exchange step is initiated even at 100 °C. As the temperature increased from 100 to 250 °C, the lactic acid peak (1720 cm-1) became progressively less intense, whereas the peaks of potassium lactate (1650 cm-1) and the BA sites became more intense. The intensity of the acrylate peak (1550 cm-1) increased gradually with temperature, suggesting that ion exchange and subsequent dehydration through the in situ-formed BA sites occurred readily on KOH-ZSM-5. Upon increasing the temperature to 300 °C, the intensity of the lactic acid and lactate peaks decreased sharply, whereas that of acrylate increased at the expense of these two molecules, suggesting that lactic acid dehydration mainly occurs at this temperature. At 350 °C, only the acrylate peak was visible, indicating that the dehydration of lactic acid was complete. Unlike the case with NaNO3-ZSM-5, the IR spectra of the KOH-ZSM-5 clearly demonstrate that the reaction progresses through the formation of lactate and in-situ BA sites, which agrees well with the high AA selectivity (∼68%) of the catalyst. Overall, these results suggest that facile ion exchange of the alkali ions in ZSM-5 with the protons in lactic acid, followed by the in situ formation of BA sites is the key step for AA formation, that is, the first ion-exchange step. The acid–base properties of the catalyst can be tuned by controlling the type of alkali cation and the degree of ion exchange, which are plausibly the two parameters that directly affect the catalyst selectivity. 3.4 Stability and durability of KOH-ZSM-5 To confirm the stability and durability of KOH-ZSM-5, which exhibited the highest AA selectivity (∼65%) and the lowest carbon deposition, a long-term activity test was performed over the course of 100 h, as shown in Fig. 9. The LA conversion remained constant between 98–100% up to 100 h. Furthermore, the product selectivity was almost unchanged, showing an average selectivity of 67, 28, and 0.8% for AA, AD, and 2,3-PD, as well as 3.3% for other compounds (‘Others’). Notably, the AA selectivity reached ∼71% after 52 h time-on-stream (TOS). The constant AA selectivity throughout the TOS also confirmed that the nature of the active sites of the catalyst remained the same, presumably because of low coke formation. Additionally, regeneration and reusability tests were performed because the stability of the catalyst (alkali-salt dissociation and dealumination) is an issue when reacted with acidic solutions under high-temperature hydrothermal conditions (Fig. S3 and Fig. S4). In continuous reusability tests, it was confirmed that the conversion and AA selectivity of the KOH treated catalyst was recovered by more than 99% after regeneration, demonstrating its high stability and durability. The slightly lower activity of the regenerated catalyst than the fresh catalyst can be due to the unremovable coke build-up inside the micropores with the repeated reaction-regeneration cycle, as confirmed by the TGA analysis. The applied regeneration condition (450 oC for 10 h in air flow) may be not sufficient to burn the hard coke inside the pore. Nonetheless, the XRD (Fig. S5) and the ICP analyses (not shown) of the regenerated catalyst confirmed that the structure and the composition of ZSM-5 are intact, indicating its structural stability as well as its activity durability. 4 Conclusions The effects of cations and anions in alkali salts on the degree of ion exchange in alkali zeolites and their acid–base properties, as well as the corresponding selectivity of the catalysts toward lactic acid dehydration, were systematically investigated using commercial H-ZSM-5 obtained through the calcination of NH4-ZSM-5, for the first time. First, parent H-ZSM-5 was subjected to ion-exchange to form Na-ZSM-5 using sodium salts with various anions (i.e., NO3 -, HCO3 -, HPO4 2-, and OH-), which directly affected the pH of the aqueous solution. BET and ICP measurements revealed that there was no significant change in the pore characteristics of Na-ZSM-5 at pH < 9.3, whereas the surface area and pore volume, especially mesopores, were substantially increased by treatment with NaOH solution at pH 14. Moreover, the degree of sodium exchange was a function of the solution pH; the Na/Al ratio increased from 0.83 to 1.18 when the solution pH was increased from 7.0 to 14.0, possibly due to enhanced cation transfer through SEA under basic conditions. The higher degree of Na exchange decreased the strength of the acid–base sites, thereby increasing the AA selectivity from 5% to 30% at the expense of the side product, AD, through decarbonylation. The parent ZSM-5 was also subjected to ion-exchange with various alkali cations (Na, K, Rb, and Cs) using alkali hydroxides, which have the highest ion-exchange rates. The M/Al ratios of K- and Rb-ZSM-5 were close to ∼1, whereas that of Cs-ZSM-5 was relatively low (∼0.89), suggesting that full cation exchange was limited by the larger ionic radius of Cs. The BET and TPD measurements revealed that the total surface density of acid–base sites decreased with increasing cation size, and the strength of the acid–base sites was considerably weakened compared to that of NaOH-ZSM-5, while the medium acid–base sites were completely eliminated. Pyridine-IR analysis of KOH-ZSM-5 also confirmed complete removal of the Brønsted acid sties. Thus, KOH- and RbOH-ZSM-5 exhibited remarkably high AA selectivity (∼65%), followed by CsOH-ZSM-5 (∼50%). Overall, these results demonstrate that the weakening of the strong acid/base sites in the catalysts through full exchange of the cations with weak acid sites is the key to obtaining high AA selectivity while minimizing unwanted decarbonylation. Furthermore, in-situ DRIFT analysis confirmed that the formation of surface lactate and the in-situ generation of Brønsted acid sites on KOH-ZSM-5 occurred readily at temperatures as low as 100 °C. The surface lactate is then converted to acrylate at elevated temperatures, indicating the high selectivity of KOH-ZSM-5. By contrast, neither surface lactate nor Brønsted acid sites was observed with the low-selectivity NaNO3-ZSM-5. Finally, the high activity of KOH-ZSM-5 (∼98% conversion) and high AA selectivity of up to 68% were maintained over the course of 100 h of reaction, suggesting the high resistance of the catalyst to deactivation. Overall, this study provides insight into the enigmatic ion-exchange mode of alkali zeolites in the dehydration of lactic acid to renewably generate acrylic acid, as well as guidelines for the design of improved dehydration catalysts. coredata.dc:description: This report shows that complete control of the degree of alkali exchange is possible by controlling the pH strength, and that is possible to distinguish the selectivity of the cations themselves in the lactic acid (LA) dehydration reaction by excluding undesired active sites arising from excess salts. We discovered that strong base conditions induced by alkali hydroxides (e.g., KOH) increase the degree of alkali ion exchange, and that in the absence of additional salts−such as halogen anions, oxides−the KOH-ZSM-5 catalyst exhibited high acrylic acid (AA) selectivity (∼70%) and durability (100 h). Characterization via temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) and pyridine-infrared (Py-IR) analysis revealed a full exchange of the protons bound to the Si–O–Al sites with potassium in commercial ZSM-5. In addition, structural pore expansion due to the desilication by KOH leads to significant enhancement in the selectivity for AA. The mechanistic impact of KOH treatment on lactic acid dehydration is also systematically verified by in situ IR spectroscopy.
coredata.dc:title: Designing alkali-exchanged ZSM-5 catalysts for the dehydration of lactic acid to acrylic acid
